message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: LLM-Based Multi-Agent Systems for Software Engineering: Literature Review, Vision, and the Road Ahead
Paper Abstract: Integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) into autonomous agents marks a significant shift in the research landscape by offering cognitive abilities that are competitive with human planning and reasoning. This article explores the transformative potential of integrating Large Language Models into Multi-Agent (LMA) systems for addressing complex challenges in software engineering (SE). By leveraging the collaborative and specialized abilities of multiple agents, LMA systems enable autonomous problem-solving, improve robustness, and provide scalable solutions for managing the complexity of real-world software projects. In this article, we conduct a systematic review of recent primary studies to map the current landscape of LMA applications across various stages of the software development lifecycle (SDLC). To illustrate current capabilities and limitations, we perform two case studies to demonstrate the effectiveness of state-of-the-art LMA frameworks. Additionally, we identify critical research gaps and propose a comprehensive research agenda focused on enhancing individual agent capabilities and optimizing agent synergy. Our work outlines a forward-looking vision for developing fully autonomous, scalable, and trustworthy LMA systems, laying the foundation for the evolution of Software Engineering 2.0.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multi-agent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Capabilities and Advantages

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Composition

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Key Characteristics

Multi-agent systems have important properties including autonomy where agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, and decentralization where no agent is designated as controlling.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of software engineering:

## Definition and Scope

Software engineering is a branch of both computer science and engineering focused on designing, developing, testing, and maintaining software applications.(no content)It involves applying engineering principles and computer programming expertise to develop software systems that meet user needs.

## Historical Background

In 1968, NATO organized the first conference on software engineering, which addressed emerging challenges in software development and played a key role in formalizing guidelines and best practices for creating reliable and maintainable software.(no content)The term appeared in a list of services offered by companies in the June 1965 issue of "Computers and Automation" and was used more formally in the August 1966 issue of Communications of the ACM.

## Key Institutions

In 1984, the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) was established as a federally funded research and development center headquartered on the campus of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States.

## Current Workforce

As of early 2025, there are an estimated 47.2 million software developers worldwide, representing a 50% increase from 31 million in Q1 2022.

Software engineering continues to be one of the major computing disciplines and is critical in modern systems involving Edge Computing, Internet of Things, and Cyber-physical Systems.

Here's information about Large Language Models based on the web search results:

## Definition and Overview

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)They consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.

## Key Characteristics

The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.

However, these models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Capabilities and Applications

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. Additionally, open-weight LLMs have increasingly shaped the field since 2023, contributing to broader participation in AI development and greater transparency in model evaluation.

Here's information about Large Language Models based on the web search results:

## Definition and Overview

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.(no content)They consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.

## Key Characteristics

The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.(no content)LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.

However, these models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Capabilities and Applications

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. Additionally, open-weight LLMs have increasingly shaped the field since 2023, contributing to broader participation in AI development and greater transparency in model evaluation.

Links: [{"title":"Systems development life cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_development_life_cycle"},{"title":"Software release life cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_release_life_cycle"},{"title":"Software development process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_development_process"},{"title":"Agile software development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agile_software_development"},{"title":"Web engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_engineering"},{"title":"Application lifecycle management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_lifecycle_management"},{"title":"V-model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V-model"},{"title":"Collaborative development environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_development_environment"},{"title":"Process development execution system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_development_execution_system"},{"title":"Micro Focus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro_Focus"}]

Here are the search results for "Software development lifecycle":

## Overview

The systems development life cycle (SDLC) describes the typical phases and progression between phases during the development of a computer-based system; from inception to retirement.

## Key Phases

The SDLC includes several important phases:

- **Construction/Implementation**: Hardware and software components are created and integrated, including testing of sub-components and components.

- **Acceptance/System Testing**: The acceptance phase is about testing the complete system to ensure that it meets customer expectations (requirements).

- **Deployment**: The deployment phase involves the logistics of delivery to the customer.

- **Maintenance**: During the maintenance phase, development is largely inactive although this phase does include customer support for resolving user issues and recording suggestions for improvement.

- **Decommission**: Decommission is when the system is removed from use, when it reaches end-of-life.

## Development Methodologies

Various methodologies have been devised, including waterfall, spiral, agile, rapid prototyping, incremental, and synchronize and stabilize.(no content)The waterfall model is a sequential development approach, in which development flows one-way (like a waterfall) through the SDLC phases.

Web search results for query: "Autonomous agents artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Agentic AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_agent"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"AutoGPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auto-GPT"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about autonomous agents in artificial intelligence:

## Definition and Core Concept

An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently. More specifically, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Key Characteristics

Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight. They possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems.(no content)Various concepts commonly associated with agents include persistence (code runs continuously and decides when to perform activity), autonomy (agents have capabilities of task selection, prioritization, goal-directed behavior, and decision-making without human intervention), social ability (agents can engage other components through communication and coordination), and reactivity (agents perceive context and react appropriately).

## Modern Agentic AI Systems

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems or agentic AI) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.(no content)A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request. Prominent examples include Devin AI, AutoGPT, and SIMA.

## Real-World Applications

Staffordshire Police announced that they would trial Agentforce agents for handling non-emergency 101 calls starting in 2026. By December 2025, the Department of Neighborhoods in Detroit, Michigan deployed a pilot project for an AI agent to be used for customer service calls. In December 2025, the Food and Drug Administration announced that it would offer "agentic AI capabilities" to its staff for meeting management, pre-market reviews, review validation, post-market surveillance, inspections and compliance and administrative functions.

I've found comprehensive information about planning and scheduling algorithms. Here's an overview of the key findings:

## Overview

Automated planning and scheduling is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

## Core Concepts

Given a description of the possible initial states of the world, a description of the desired goals, and a description of a set of possible actions, the planning problem is to synthesize a plan that is guaranteed to generate a state which contains the desired goals.

## Types of Scheduling Algorithms

The search results reveal several categories:

**Computing/Process Scheduling:** A scheduling discipline is an algorithm used for distributing resources among parties which simultaneously and asynchronously request them. Scheduling disciplines are used in routers, operating systems, disk drives, printers, and most embedded systems. Common algorithms include FIFO (First In, First Out), which simply queues processes in the order that they arrive in the ready queue.

**Production Scheduling:** Scheduling is the process of arranging, controlling and optimizing work and workloads in a production process. It is used to allocate plant and machinery resources, plan human resources, plan production processes and purchase materials, and is an important tool for manufacturing and engineering.

**Advanced Planning and Scheduling (APS):** APS refers to a manufacturing management process by which raw materials and production capacity are optimally allocated to meet demand.

## Specific Algorithm Examples

The genetic algorithm is an operational research method that may be used to solve scheduling problems in production planning.(no content)The Graphical Path Method (GPM) is a mathematically based algorithm used in project management for planning, scheduling and resource control, and represents logical relationships of dated objects in a time-scaled network diagram.(no content)Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995 that takes as input a planning problem expressed in STRIPS and produces a sequence of operations for reaching a goal state.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title; relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes); entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other; wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/); relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
